category.name: General Informations
category.question:
What is this project good for?
Please provide here few lines describing the the project, what problem it should solve, provide links to documentation, specifications, etc.

category.name: Project and platform dependencies
category.question:
What other NetBeans projects this one depends on?
If you want, describe such projects as imported API using the <api name="identification" type="import or export" category="stable" url="where is the description" />

What other non-NetBeans projects this one depends on?
Some non-NetBeans projects are packaged as NetBeans modules (see libraries) and it is prefered to use this approach when more modules may depend on such third-party library.

On which platforms your module run? Any? Does it run in the same way?
If your module is using JNI or deals with special differences of OSes like filesystems, etc. please describe here what they are.

Which version of JRE you need (1.2, 1.3, 1.4, etc.)?
It is expected that if your module runs on 1.x that it will run on 1.x+1 if no, state that please. Also describe here cases where you run different code on different versions of JRE and why.
Do you require JDK or is JRE enough?

category.name: Deployment
category.question:
Do you deploy just module JAR file(s) or some other files?
If your module consist just from one module JAR file, just confirm that. If it uses more than one JAR, describe where there are located, how they refer to each other. If it consist of module JAR(s) and other files, please describe what is their purpose, why other files are necessary. Please make sure that installation/deinstallation leaves the system in state as it was before installation.

Can you deploy NBM via AutoUpdate center?
If not why?

Do you need to be installed in shared location or only in user directory?
Installation location shall not matter, if it does explain why.

Are packages of your module made inaccessible by not declaring them public?
NetBeans module system allows restriction of access rights to public classes of your module from other modules. This prevents unwanted dependencies of others on your code and should be used whenever possible ( public packages ).

category.name: Compatiblity with environment
category.question:
Is your module correctly internationalized?
Correct internationalization means that it obeys instuctions at NetBeans I18N pages.
Does the module implements or defines any standards? Is the implementation exact or it deviates somehow?

Does your module properly coexists with earlier and future versions? Can you correctly read settings? Will future versions be able to read settings?
Very helpful for reading settings is to store version number there, so future versions can decide whether how to read/convert the settings and older versions can ignore the new ones.

category.name: Access to resources
category.question:
Does your module use java.io.File directly?
NetBeans provide a logical wrapper over plain files called org.openide.filesystems.FileObject that provides uniform access to such resources and is the prefered way that should be used. But of course there can be situations when this is not suitable.

Does your module provide own layer? Does it create some files or folders on it? What it is trying to communicate by that and with which component?
NetBeans allows automatic and declarative installation of resources by module layers. Module register files into appropriate places and other components use that information to perform their task (build menu, toolbar, window layout, list of templates, set of options, etc.).

Does your module read any resources from layers? For what purpose?
As this is some kind of intermodule dependency, it is a kind of API. Please describe it and clasify according to
common stability categories.

Does your module mask/hide/override any resource provided by another one in module layer?
If you mask a file provided by another module, you probably depend on that and do not want the other module to (for example) change the file's name. That module shall thus make that file available as an API of some stability category.

category.name: Lookup of components
category.question:
Does your module uses org.openide.util.Lookup to find any components to communicate to? Which ones?
Please describe the interfaces you are searching for, where are defined, whether you are searching for just one or more of them, if the order is important, etc. Also clasify the stability of such API contract.

Do you register anything into the lookup for other to find?
Do you register using layer file or using META-INF/services? Who is supposed to find your component?

Are removing entries of other modules from the lookup?
Why? Of course, that is possible, but it can be dangerous. Is the module your are masking resource from aware of what you are doing?

category.name: Execution Environment
category.question:
Is execution of your code influenced by any environment of system (System.getProperty) property?
If there is a property that can change the behaviour of your code, somebody will likely use it. You should describe what it does and the stability category of this API. You may use
<property name="id" category="private" &gt description of the property, where it is used, what it influence, etc. </property>
Is execution of your code influenced by (string) property of any of your components?
Does your code uses own classloader?

category.name: Format of files and protocols
category.question: Which file formats your code reads or writes on disk?
Which protocols your code understands during drag-n-drop?
Which protocols your code reads/inserts when communicating with clipboard?

category.name: Performance and Scalability
category.question: Does your module executes anything on startup?
Does your module executes anything on exit?

Which external criteria influence the performance of your program (size of file in editor, number of files in menu, in source directory, etc.) and how well your code scales? Please include some estimates.
Are there any limits in number/size of elements your code can handle?
What is the amount of memory your component occupies? Estimate with a relaction to the number of windows, etc.
Is any piece of your code waking up periodically?

Does your module executes some long running task? Typically they are tasks like connecting over network, computing huge amount of data, compilation. Such communication should be done asynchronously (for example using RequestProcessor), definitively it should not block AWT thread.
Does your module contain any dialogs or wizards with huge amount of GUI controls like combo boxes, lists, trees, text areas?
Does your module use dynamically changing context menus or context sensitive actions with complicated logic for enable/disable?
